issue.title: Support `hedgehog-1.2`
issue.body: Support `hedgehog-1.2` and resolve #61.

comment.body: I have run the test suite on this branch on all the GHC versions we support, and they passed. I've asked a friend to test this version on his project.

issue.title: Support `hedgehog-1.2`
issue.body:
This is a draft PR to support `hedgehog-1.2` and resolve #61. I have made this a draft for now, because:

- These are breaking changes and drop support for older versions of `hedgehog`, due to the change to `HedgehogReplay`, which is exported. I could work around this with `CPP` enabled, or with some Cabal conditions / module magic.
- We might want to release #62 as a point release before this.

I expect most of the CI workflows to fail due to the new lower version bound.

comment.body: Thank you! Feel free to release.

issue.title: Support `hedgehog-1.2`
issue.body:
This is a draft PR to support `hedgehog-1.2` and resolve #61. I have made this a draft for now, because:

- These are breaking changes and drop support for older versions of `hedgehog`, due to the change to `HedgehogReplay`, which is exported. I could work around this with `CPP` enabled, or with some Cabal conditions / module magic.
- We might want to release #62 as a point release before this.

I expect most of the CI workflows to fail due to the new lower version bound.

comment.body:
>might want to release #62 as a point release before this
I reckon we probably should, since this upcoming version will be a big cut-off point, at which some people will find themselves stuck.

>CI failures, CPP
I would prefer us to support all GHC versions that our hedgehog  bounds support, but I don't think it's worth the extra effort of adding CPP to support older hedgehog versions (and thereby older GHC versions). If someone needs to use an older version of hedgehog, they can use an older versions of tasty-hedgehog too.

review.body: Looks good to me, go ahead. Thank you for all your efforts!

pull_request.title: Improve instructions for reproducing failures
pull_request.body:
(This is some work I have been doing as part of #61, but I think it is separate enough for its own PR.)

The current default behaviour of `tasty-hedgehog` is to print instructions for how to reproduce a failure from the command-line (unless `--hedgehog-show-replay=false` is set):

```
Use '--hedgehog-replay "Size 1 Seed 11085113227810269959 15859081617099903151"' to reproduce.
```

There are two points here that I want to discuss / address:

1. If these instructions are followed, _all_ tests will be re-run with the given size and seed. That's not a huge problem until we support `hedgehog-1.3` where it is definitely not desired behaviour, but it may already be unexpected/unhelpful. This PR modifies the instructions to include a `--pattern` switch in the instructions which filters the tests down to the one(s) with the name of the failed test (see my note below).
2. The instructions follow Hedgehog's own instructions for reproducing test failures in GHCi:
```
This failure can be reproduced by running:
> recheck (Size 1) (Seed 11085113227810269959 15859081617099903151) prop_badReverse_involutive
```
For novices, it might be somewhat confusing to get two very similar replay instructions back-to-back. I have added the text "from the command-line" at the end of `tasty-hedgehog`'s instructions to more clearly distinguish what the instructions are for.

With these two changes, the output for a test failure is now:
```
Use '--pattern "$NF ~ /badReverse involutive fails/" --hedgehog-replay "Size 1 Seed 11085113227810269959 15859081617099903151"' to reproduce from the command-line.
```

There are now API changes as a result of these changes.

I am slightly unhappy about the `--pattern` value, since it only uses the `TestName`, rather than the full test `Path`, but I do not see a way to access that in `run` without modifying `tasty` itself and providing the full test `Path` as an extra argument to `run` (which would be a breaking change there).

repo.name: tasty-hedgehog
repo.description: Tasty integration for the Hedgehog property testing library

issue.title: Support Hedgehog Skipping
issue.body:
The next version of Hedgehog will have "skipping" (https://github.com/hedgehogqa/haskell-hedgehog/pull/454). It will also break `Internal` APIs that we depend on.

We should at least upgrade to build successfully with the new version, and it would be good to support the skipping functionality as well. @mbg Would you like to have a go at this? I could do the former option myself but don't have time for the latter.

comment.body: I've tested and made a metadata revision to tasty-hedgehog-1.3.0.0 to allow hedgehog-1.1.2

issue.title: Support Hedgehog Skipping
issue.body:
The next version of Hedgehog will have "skipping" (https://github.com/hedgehogqa/haskell-hedgehog/pull/454). It will also break `Internal` APIs that we depend on.

We should at least upgrade to build successfully with the new version, and it would be good to support the skipping functionality as well. @mbg Would you like to have a go at this? I could do the former option myself but don't have time for the latter.

comment.body: This sounds like a complex situation with no good answers. What you've described sounds reasonable to me. At this point, you're more up to date on Hedgehog internals than I am :)

issue.title: Make `PropertyName` optional and undeprecate `testProperty`
issue.body:
As a result of #58, I reviewed Hedgehog's code and noticed that `PropertyName` is actually optional in https://github.com/hedgehogqa/haskell-hedgehog/blob/f3473dfb4ea817222a09033a90d15bd30ce07f89/hedgehog/src/Hedgehog/Internal/Report.hs#L583-L593 which in turn led me to discover that `renderResult` also accepts a `Maybe PropertyName`.

I have changed the representation of the `HP` constructor to accept a `Maybe PropertyName` instead of a `PropertyName`. Therefore, we can now set that argument to `Nothing` in `testProperty` an undeprecate it, which resolves #58.

comment.body: Thank you!

commits.message:
Make `PropertyName` optional in `HP`

- `renderResult` accepts a `Maybe PropertyName`
- If that is `Nothing`, `<property>` is rendered instead of an expr
- Undeprecate `testProperty` and set `PropertyName` to `Nothing`

Merge pull request #59 from mbg/improve/optional-property-name

Make `PropertyName` optional and undeprecate `testProperty`

issue.title: Undeprecate `testProperty`
issue.body: Could I ask that `testProperty` not be deprecated? I understand that `testPropertyNamed` gives a better error message, but this mostly relies on a `Property` being a top-level function. There are many times where I generate a property based on in-scope variables, at which point I don't really have a top-level function (that is, whatever Hedgehog tells me to re-run is going to be wrong). `testProperty` feels like the right function to use here, even though the repro message is going to be wrong - I can live with that. I can of course turn off deprecations on my projects, but that's a big hammer.

pull_request.title: Make `PropertyName` optional and undeprecate `testProperty`
pull_request.body:
As a result of #58, I reviewed Hedgehog's code and noticed that `PropertyName` is actually optional in https://github.com/hedgehogqa/haskell-hedgehog/blob/f3473dfb4ea817222a09033a90d15bd30ce07f89/hedgehog/src/Hedgehog/Internal/Report.hs#L583-L593 which in turn led me to discover that `renderResult` also accepts a `Maybe PropertyName`.

I have changed the representation of the `HP` constructor to accept a `Maybe PropertyName` instead of a `PropertyName`. Therefore, we can now set that argument to `Nothing` in `testProperty` an undeprecate it, which resolves #58.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -91,9 +91,8 @@ data FailedAnnotation =
 
 data FailureReport =
   FailureReport {
-      failureSize :: !Size
-    , failureSeed :: !Seed
-    , failureShrinks :: !ShrinkCount
+      failureShrinks :: !ShrinkCount
comment.body:
It looks like our bounds are conservative enough already that you should be right to release. Go ahead!
I've created an issue on tasty-hedgehog to support the functionality here https://github.com/qfpl/tasty-hedgehog/issues/61

pull_request.title: Allow skipping to a specific test number or shrink result
pull_request.body:
This won't be good to merge as-is, but if the feature is desirable, I'd be happy to help get it ready, including making supporting PRs to other repositories. (hspec-hedgehog will need one, and support for the feature in hspec would be nice.)

Using environment variables, this lets the user either

* `HEDGEHOG_SKIP_TO_TEST`: Start testing at a specific test number, and then continue from there. If it fails it'll shrink, if it passes it'll move on to the next test. Or,
* `HEDGEHOG_SKIP_TO_SHRINK`: Test at a specific test number and shrink state. If it fails it won't shrink further, if it passes the test will pass. The shrink state is encoded as an alphanumeric string and printed below the test and shrink counts.

Caveat: I don't think it's possible to walk the shrink tree without running tests at all? Please correct me if I'm wrong about that. So in the second case, you run the test at the desired shrink state, plus all its parents in the tree. But you don't run it at any of the shrinks that didn't cause the test to fail.

The value for me is that when retrying tests, they often spend several minutes before they reach the failing test case. This can eliminate almost all of that time. Additionally, I often use print-debugging, and that gets awkward if there's output from passing tests below the output from the failed test. By telling the runner exactly where to stop shrinking, that problem goes away.

repo.name: haskell-hedgehog
repo.description: Release with confidence, state-of-the-art property testing for Haskell.

repo.name: haskell-hedgehog
repo.description: Release with confidence, state-of-the-art property testing for Haskell.

issue.title: Allow base-4.17 (GHC 9.4)
issue.body:
Tested using

    cabal test -w ghc-9.4.1 --allow-newer=hedgehog:template-haskell

The allow-newer is not necessary when hedgehogqa/haskell-hedgehog#461 is released. It is already merged.

comment.body: Thanks for this, I've made a metadata revision accordingly.

commits.message:
Merge pull request #60 from ysangkok/janus/allow-ghc-9.4

Allow base-4.17 (GHC 9.4)

issue.title: Undeprecate `testProperty`
issue.body: Could I ask that `testProperty` not be deprecated? I understand that `testPropertyNamed` gives a better error message, but this mostly relies on a `Property` being a top-level function. There are many times where I generate a property based on in-scope variables, at which point I don't really have a top-level function (that is, whatever Hedgehog tells me to re-run is going to be wrong). `testProperty` feels like the right function to use here, even though the repro message is going to be wrong - I can live with that. I can of course turn off deprecations on my projects, but that's a big hammer.

comment.body:
This seems reasonable and I'm leaning towards doing it. Maybe just adding a comment to `testProperty` that `testPropertyNamed` is usually the one you want.
@mbg @andreabedini  What do you think of this?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -91,9 +91,8 @@ data FailedAnnotation =
 
 data FailureReport =
   FailureReport {
-      failureSize :: !Size
-    , failureSeed :: !Seed
-    , failureShrinks :: !ShrinkCount
+      failureShrinks :: !ShrinkCount
comment.body:
Looks like this will break us. I'm happy to change to the new type and revise affected older versions. No worries :)
Since there are a couple of libraries downstream though, could we consider perhaps un-"internal"-ing this in a future release? It would be nice (from my perspective at least) if this API were covered under the PVP version number.

pull_request.title: Improve instructions for reproducing failures
pull_request.body:
(This is some work I have been doing as part of #61, but I think it is separate enough for its own PR.)

The current default behaviour of `tasty-hedgehog` is to print instructions for how to reproduce a failure from the command-line (unless `--hedgehog-show-replay=false` is set):

```
Use '--hedgehog-replay "Size 1 Seed 11085113227810269959 15859081617099903151"' to reproduce.
```

There are two points here that I want to discuss / address:

1. If these instructions are followed, _all_ tests will be re-run with the given size and seed. That's not a huge problem until we support `hedgehog-1.3` where it is definitely not desired behaviour, but it may already be unexpected/unhelpful. This PR modifies the instructions to include a `--pattern` switch in the instructions which filters the tests down to the one(s) with the name of the failed test (see my note below).
2. The instructions follow Hedgehog's own instructions for reproducing test failures in GHCi:
```
This failure can be reproduced by running:
> recheck (Size 1) (Seed 11085113227810269959 15859081617099903151) prop_badReverse_involutive
```
For novices, it might be somewhat confusing to get two very similar replay instructions back-to-back. I have added the text "from the command-line" at the end of `tasty-hedgehog`'s instructions to more clearly distinguish what the instructions are for.

With these two changes, the output for a test failure is now:
```
Use '--pattern "$NF ~ /badReverse involutive fails/" --hedgehog-replay "Size 1 Seed 11085113227810269959 15859081617099903151"' to reproduce from the command-line.
```

There are now API changes as a result of these changes.

I am slightly unhappy about the `--pattern` value, since it only uses the `TestName`, rather than the full test `Path`, but I do not see a way to access that in `run` without modifying `tasty` itself and providing the full test `Path` as an extra argument to `run` (which would be a breaking change there).

pull_request.title: Allow skipping to a specific test number or shrink result
pull_request.body:
This won't be good to merge as-is, but if the feature is desirable, I'd be happy to help get it ready, including making supporting PRs to other repositories. (hspec-hedgehog will need one, and support for the feature in hspec would be nice.)

Using environment variables, this lets the user either

* `HEDGEHOG_SKIP_TO_TEST`: Start testing at a specific test number, and then continue from there. If it fails it'll shrink, if it passes it'll move on to the next test. Or,
* `HEDGEHOG_SKIP_TO_SHRINK`: Test at a specific test number and shrink state. If it fails it won't shrink further, if it passes the test will pass. The shrink state is encoded as an alphanumeric string and printed below the test and shrink counts.

Caveat: I don't think it's possible to walk the shrink tree without running tests at all? Please correct me if I'm wrong about that. So in the second case, you run the test at the desired shrink state, plus all its parents in the tree. But you don't run it at any of the shrinks that didn't cause the test to fail.

The value for me is that when retrying tests, they often spend several minutes before they reach the failing test case. This can eliminate almost all of that time. Additionally, I often use print-debugging, and that gets awkward if there's output from passing tests below the output from the failed test. By telling the runner exactly where to stop shrinking, that problem goes away.

repo.name: haskell-hedgehog
repo.description: Release with confidence, state-of-the-art property testing for Haskell.

repo.name: haskell-hedgehog
repo.description: Release with confidence, state-of-the-art property testing for Haskell.

issue.title: Support Hedgehog Skipping
issue.body:
The next version of Hedgehog will have "skipping" (https://github.com/hedgehogqa/haskell-hedgehog/pull/454). It will also break `Internal` APIs that we depend on.

We should at least upgrade to build successfully with the new version, and it would be good to support the skipping functionality as well. @mbg Would you like to have a go at this? I could do the former option myself but don't have time for the latter.

issue.title: Make `PropertyName` optional and undeprecate `testProperty`
issue.body:
As a result of #58, I reviewed Hedgehog's code and noticed that `PropertyName` is actually optional in https://github.com/hedgehogqa/haskell-hedgehog/blob/f3473dfb4ea817222a09033a90d15bd30ce07f89/hedgehog/src/Hedgehog/Internal/Report.hs#L583-L593 which in turn led me to discover that `renderResult` also accepts a `Maybe PropertyName`.

I have changed the representation of the `HP` constructor to accept a `Maybe PropertyName` instead of a `PropertyName`. Therefore, we can now set that argument to `Nothing` in `testProperty` an undeprecate it, which resolves #58.

comment.body: @mbg This looks good, thank you. I intend to merge this and release it as 1.3.0.0. Before I merge, can you please add a changelog entry to `changelog.md` explaining what you've done?

issue.title: Allow base-4.17 (GHC 9.4)
issue.body:
Tested using

    cabal test -w ghc-9.4.1 --allow-newer=hedgehog:template-haskell

The allow-newer is not necessary when hedgehogqa/haskell-hedgehog#461 is released. It is already merged.

comment.body: Thanks for this, I've made a metadata revision accordingly.

commits.message:
Merge pull request #60 from ysangkok/janus/allow-ghc-9.4

Allow base-4.17 (GHC 9.4)

repo.name: tasty-hedgehog
repo.description: Tasty integration for the Hedgehog property testing library

issue.title: Undeprecate `testProperty`
issue.body: Could I ask that `testProperty` not be deprecated? I understand that `testPropertyNamed` gives a better error message, but this mostly relies on a `Property` being a top-level function. There are many times where I generate a property based on in-scope variables, at which point I don't really have a top-level function (that is, whatever Hedgehog tells me to re-run is going to be wrong). `testProperty` feels like the right function to use here, even though the repro message is going to be wrong - I can live with that. I can of course turn off deprecations on my projects, but that's a big hammer.

comment.body:
This seems reasonable and I'm leaning towards doing it. Maybe just adding a comment to `testProperty` that `testPropertyNamed` is usually the one you want.
@mbg @andreabedini  What do you think of this?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -91,9 +91,8 @@ data FailedAnnotation =
 
 data FailureReport =
   FailureReport {
-      failureSize :: !Size
-    , failureSeed :: !Seed
-    , failureShrinks :: !ShrinkCount
+      failureShrinks :: !ShrinkCount
comment.body:
Looks like this will break us. I'm happy to change to the new type and revise affected older versions. No worries :)
Since there are a couple of libraries downstream though, could we consider perhaps un-"internal"-ing this in a future release? It would be nice (from my perspective at least) if this API were covered under the PVP version number.

issue.title: Support `hedgehog-1.2`
issue.body: Support `hedgehog-1.2` and resolve #61.

comment.body: I have run the test suite on this branch on all the GHC versions we support, and they passed. I've asked a friend to test this version on his project.

issue.title: Support `hedgehog-1.2`
issue.body:
This is a draft PR to support `hedgehog-1.2` and resolve #61. I have made this a draft for now, because:

- These are breaking changes and drop support for older versions of `hedgehog`, due to the change to `HedgehogReplay`, which is exported. I could work around this with `CPP` enabled, or with some Cabal conditions / module magic.
- We might want to release #62 as a point release before this.

I expect most of the CI workflows to fail due to the new lower version bound.

comment.body: Thank you! Feel free to release.

issue.title: Support `hedgehog-1.2`
issue.body:
This is a draft PR to support `hedgehog-1.2` and resolve #61. I have made this a draft for now, because:

- These are breaking changes and drop support for older versions of `hedgehog`, due to the change to `HedgehogReplay`, which is exported. I could work around this with `CPP` enabled, or with some Cabal conditions / module magic.
- We might want to release #62 as a point release before this.

I expect most of the CI workflows to fail due to the new lower version bound.

comment.body:
>might want to release #62 as a point release before this
I reckon we probably should, since this upcoming version will be a big cut-off point, at which some people will find themselves stuck.

>CI failures, CPP
I would prefer us to support all GHC versions that our hedgehog  bounds support, but I don't think it's worth the extra effort of adding CPP to support older hedgehog versions (and thereby older GHC versions). If someone needs to use an older version of hedgehog, they can use an older versions of tasty-hedgehog too.

review.body: Looks good to me, go ahead. Thank you for all your efforts!

pull_request.title: Improve instructions for reproducing failures
pull_request.body:
(This is some work I have been doing as part of #61, but I think it is separate enough for its own PR.)

The current default behaviour of `tasty-hedgehog` is to print instructions for how to reproduce a failure from the command-line (unless `--hedgehog-show-replay=false` is set):

```
Use '--hedgehog-replay "Size 1 Seed 11085113227810269959 15859081617099903151"' to reproduce.
```

There are two points here that I want to discuss / address:

1. If these instructions are followed, _all_ tests will be re-run with the given size and seed. That's not a huge problem until we support `hedgehog-1.3` where it is definitely not desired behaviour, but it may already be unexpected/unhelpful. This PR modifies the instructions to include a `--pattern` switch in the instructions which filters the tests down to the one(s) with the name of the failed test (see my note below).
2. The instructions follow Hedgehog's own instructions for reproducing test failures in GHCi:
```
This failure can be reproduced by running:
> recheck (Size 1) (Seed 11085113227810269959 15859081617099903151) prop_badReverse_involutive
```
For novices, it might be somewhat confusing to get two very similar replay instructions back-to-back. I have added the text "from the command-line" at the end of `tasty-hedgehog`'s instructions to more clearly distinguish what the instructions are for.

With these two changes, the output for a test failure is now:
```
Use '--pattern "$NF ~ /badReverse involutive fails/" --hedgehog-replay "Size 1 Seed 11085113227810269959 15859081617099903151"' to reproduce from the command-line.
```

There are now API changes as a result of these changes.

I am slightly unhappy about the `--pattern` value, since it only uses the `TestName`, rather than the full test `Path`, but I do not see a way to access that in `run` without modifying `tasty` itself and providing the full test `Path` as an extra argument to `run` (which would be a breaking change there).

repo.description: Tasty integration for the Hedgehog property testing library

issue.title: Make `PropertyName` optional and undeprecate `testProperty`
issue.body:
As a result of #58, I reviewed Hedgehog's code and noticed that `PropertyName` is actually optional in https://github.com/hedgehogqa/haskell-hedgehog/blob/f3473dfb4ea817222a09033a90d15bd30ce07f89/hedgehog/src/Hedgehog/Internal/Report.hs#L583-L593 which in turn led me to discover that `renderResult` also accepts a `Maybe PropertyName`.

I have changed the representation of the `HP` constructor to accept a `Maybe PropertyName` instead of a `PropertyName`. Therefore, we can now set that argument to `Nothing` in `testProperty` an undeprecate it, which resolves #58.

comment.body: Thank you!

commits.message:
Make `PropertyName` optional in `HP`

- `renderResult` accepts a `Maybe PropertyName`
- If that is `Nothing`, `<property>` is rendered instead of an expr
- Undeprecate `testProperty` and set `PropertyName` to `Nothing`

Merge pull request #59 from mbg/improve/optional-property-name

Make `PropertyName` optional and undeprecate `testProperty`

pull_request.title: Allow skipping to a specific test number or shrink result
pull_request.body:
This won't be good to merge as-is, but if the feature is desirable, I'd be happy to help get it ready, including making supporting PRs to other repositories. (hspec-hedgehog will need one, and support for the feature in hspec would be nice.)

Using environment variables, this lets the user either

* `HEDGEHOG_SKIP_TO_TEST`: Start testing at a specific test number, and then continue from there. If it fails it'll shrink, if it passes it'll move on to the next test. Or,
* `HEDGEHOG_SKIP_TO_SHRINK`: Test at a specific test number and shrink state. If it fails it won't shrink further, if it passes the test will pass. The shrink state is encoded as an alphanumeric string and printed below the test and shrink counts.

Caveat: I don't think it's possible to walk the shrink tree without running tests at all? Please correct me if I'm wrong about that. So in the second case, you run the test at the desired shrink state, plus all its parents in the tree. But you don't run it at any of the shrinks that didn't cause the test to fail.

The value for me is that when retrying tests, they often spend several minutes before they reach the failing test case. This can eliminate almost all of that time. Additionally, I often use print-debugging, and that gets awkward if there's output from passing tests below the output from the failed test. By telling the runner exactly where to stop shrinking, that problem goes away.

repo.name: haskell-hedgehog
repo.description: Release with confidence, state-of-the-art property testing for Haskell.

repo.description: Release with confidence, state-of-the-art property testing for Haskell.
